attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a physical count of raw materials and finished product on 17th April 2025 to determine the effectiveness and adequacy of existing stock controls at the branch.
  • The findings were listed and tabulated below:
    • Polybags had a variance of -4,721 pieces
    • The finished product had a variance of -180 pieces
    • Utto oil had a variance of 8.434 Litres/Kgs
    • Wheat Bran had a variation of 69.727 Kgs
    • Yeast had a variance of -2.038 pieces as shown below:
attributes.recommendation:
• The branch management should strengthen the raw materials, polybags and finished product movement controls.
  • Close monitoring of raw materials’ issuance and usage at the production section is recommended
attributes.effect: • Variances in stock items, given that weekly stock adjustments were made by the operations team, implied weak stock controls.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• The branch management should strengthen the raw materials, polybags and finished product movement controls.
  • Close monitoring of raw materials’ issuance and usage at the production section is recommended.

value:
•  I will take total control of usage of raw materials by following up on shift wise tock takes.
  •  Deductions were raised for the bread variance noted, therefore going forward we will enhance our controls.

• The Manager has been advised to measure wheat bran issued out shift-wise to control usage and alleviate variances.
  • The previous stock had excess of +8k due to presence of polybags borrowed from D1 without using the system and since this was adjusted in the stock, it overstated the stock since the D1 polybags were returned physically after discovering this. The manager already received a verbal warning not to initiate any unapproved stock transfer. We will monitor the stock going forward for any further variances.
  • The bread variance was recovered from the Manager and going forward we will strengthen controls.

·       In the prior audit report dated 14th March 2025 stocks were as seen below:

  • Bread stock: +6.25 pieces,
  • Polybags: +2,882 pieces,
  • Wheat bran: +18.93 kg,
  • White flour: -57.63 kgs,
  • Brown flour: +36.40 kgs.

attributes.title: Bread  Weight
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A spot check on the weights of bread produced at the branch was done on 17th April 2025 to ascertain if the branch was compliant with the Weights and Measures Act (Sale of Bread Rules) Legal Notice 94 of 1970.
  • We noted instances of non-compliance to the standard weights whereby there were overweight loaves across all varieties as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to ensure adherence to the required dough/bread weight standards and weighing procedures.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The presence of overweight loaves implied lapses in adhering to the standard dough weights and losses in expected yield.
attributes.remediation_plan: • The branch management to  advise dough makers on weight consistency to prevent variations from the standard weight.

value: • The over-weights were impacted by inconsistencies in the divider’s accuracy, but we will increase spot checks to ensure such cases are minimized.
• We will advise dough makers on weight consistency to prevent variations from the standard weight.

• In the previous audit report dated 14th March 2025, packed bread underweights were noted as follows; 400g Brown - 27%
  • Over-weights were noted across all varieties.

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a review of damages arising from production and market delivery/transit processes for the period 1st March to 15th April 2025 to detect if the damage levels were within the set limits.
  • The findings were as follows:
    • The production damage was 0.287% of the total production which was above the set standard of 0.2% with a cost implication of KES 81,796.56
    • The market damage was 1.33% of the total sales (supermarket damages), which was above the 1% allowed limit and had a cost implication of KES 398,353.95 as computed below.
    • We noticed that the Market damages from credit notes since 21st March 2025 to 15th April 2025 amounting to 17,773.5 loaves were not reflected as good issues in the system due to lapses in completing the process of posting damages from credit notes.
attributes.recommendation:
• Enhance quality controls within the production and bread delivery processes to ensure there are minimal/acceptable levels of both production and market damages.
  • Training of clerks on full process of posting damages from credit notes to be done.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The production and market damage levels were above the set limits which implied unbudgeted losses/cost incurred due to excess damages.
attributes.remediation_plan:
•  Enhance quality controls within the production and bread delivery processes to ensure there are minimal/acceptable levels of both production and market damages.
  •  Training of clerks on full process of posting damages from credit notes to be done.

value: • We have had high bread demand in the market that led to rushing of the production process and this contributed to damages but we will follow up to minimize damages.

• High bread demand and shortage of crates led to packing of more breads than normal in crates which contributed to the damages, however we have requested for crates replacement to avoid this.
  • We will enhance production controls to minimize damages.
  •  We have a new clerk who did not complete the posting process but as of today we have made arrangements for the clerk to be guided by the previous clerk on how to complete the process in the system.
• During the prior audit dated 14th March 2025, it was noted that production damages were 0.33% of the production and market damages stood at 1.55% of the total sales.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted an analysis of both the mixing charts and mixing chart summaries for the period 1st March to 15th April 2025 to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.
  • The following were noted:
    • The average yield was 190.95 loaves per bag.
    • Average production was 201.96 bags equivalent to 93% of the set target of 216 bags.
    • Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
    • 1,904 cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should minimize remix cases where possible by taking preventative measures.
attributes.effect: • The high number of remixes implied lapses or mishaps in the production process.
attributes.remediation_plan: • The branch management should minimize remix cases where possible by taking preventative measures.

value:
• We had interference with cable line that led to power outages that contributed to the remixes noted.
  • We will maintain the production target achieved and improve further.

• The remixes were caused by power outage due to damaged cable as communicated by KAF on 12th and 15th March 2025.
  • We will maintain the production target achieved due to improved sales.

During the prior audit, the following were noted:

  • Average yield 191.08
  • Average production 185.75 bags.
  • 2,022 remixes were observed.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was done on the efficiency of criteria for labour allocation to the production section for the period 1st March to 15th April 2025.
  • We noted that the average production efficiency was 4.36 bags per production worker which surpassed the set standard of 4.5.
  • The results were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • Branch management to maintain optimal allocation of employees to the production section.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The branch had optimal allocation of workers therefore implying controlled labour cost of production.

value: • The previous audit report dated 14th March 2025 indicated a production efficiency of 4.34 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An assessment was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if optimality was attained based on the set Company standard of 97 crates per packer.
  • We noted that, for the period 1st March to 15th April 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 117.54 crates per packer, which exceeded the set standard as demonstrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to maintain optimal allocation of packers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: • The branch surpassed the set target due to large varieties of bread packed and optimal allocation of packers hired which implied well-controlled labour costs.

value: • The previous audit report dated 14th March 2025 indicated a packing efficiency of 93.32 crates per packer.
• The branch attained the set slicing efficiency implying optimal allocation of packers.

attributes.title: Vehicle Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 1st April to 22nd April 2025.
  • 5 out of 18 route vehicles had excess fuel consumption ranging from 7 to 15 Litres each while 13 out of 18 other route vehicles’ fuel consumption was within the set standard as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • Strengthen the fuel management controls within the branch across all routes.
attributes.effect: • Fuel consumption for vehicles at the branch was well controlled except for the few vehicles that require improvement in existing controls.

value: • We will follow up and control the fuel approved to the vehicles.
• We will follow up and control the fuel approved to the vehicles.
• During the previous audit dated 14th March 2025, overconsumption was noted in the Mesora route by 20 litres and faulty speedometers for KCH 425T and KTWC 550E.
• Fuel consumption for vehicles at the branch was well controlled except for the few vehicles that require improvement in existing controls.
